skills.name: Customer Success
skills.description:
Acquisition is expensive. Retention is profitable. Customer success is the
discipline of ensuring customers achieve their desired outcomes with your
product - which leads to retention, expansion, and advocacy.

This skill covers onboarding that activates, health scoring that predicts,
retention plays that save, and expansion strategies that grow accounts.

principles.name: Time to value is everything
principles.description:
The faster users get value, the more likely they stick. Measure and
optimize time to first value moment. Remove every obstacle between
signup and aha moment.

examples.good: User sees value in first session, under 5 minutes
examples.bad: Value requires days of setup, learning, configuration

principles.name: Proactive beats reactive
principles.description:
Reach out before problems escalate. Health scores predict churn before
it happens. Intervention when metrics dip is worth 10x intervention
after cancellation request.

examples.good: Alert when usage drops, proactive check-in call
examples.bad: Notice churn only when credit card fails

principles.name: Segment for relevance
principles.description:
Not all customers are the same. High-touch for enterprise, tech-touch
for SMB, self-serve for individuals. Match effort to customer value
and needs.

examples.good: Dedicated CSM for enterprise, automated sequences for self-serve
examples.bad: Same email blast to everyone regardless of tier

principles.name: Measure leading indicators
principles.description:
Revenue is a lagging indicator. By the time it drops, damage is done.
Track leading indicators: engagement, feature adoption, support tickets,
NPS changes.

examples.good: Dashboard with daily engagement, weekly feature adoption, monthly NPS
examples.bad: Only looking at MRR and wondering why it dropped

principles.name: Make expansion natural
principles.description:
Upselling should feel like helping, not selling. When customers outgrow
their tier, expansion is a solution. When they hit limits, upgrade is
obvious.

examples.good: Usage-based nudge when approaching limits with clear value prop
examples.bad: Aggressive sales calls pushing features they do not need

patterns.name: Activation Milestones
patterns.description: Define specific value moments users must hit to become activated
patterns.when: Designing onboarding flows or measuring activation success
patterns.example:
Instead of: "User logged in = activated"
Define specific value milestones:

Slack: Team sent 2,000 messages
Dropbox: User added 1 file from 1 device
Superhuman: User processed inbox to zero once

Benefits:
- Clear target for onboarding design
- Predictive of retention (activated users stay)
- Actionable metric to optimize

Track time-to-activation and activation rate. Both should trend down over time

patterns.name: Proactive Health Monitoring
patterns.description: Build health scores that predict churn before users decide to leave
patterns.when: Designing customer success operations and intervention playbooks
patterns.example:
Health Score Components:
1. Product usage (40%): DAU trend, feature adoption depth
2. Support health (20%): Ticket volume, sentiment, unresolved issues
3. Relationship (20%): Last CSM touch, executive engagement
4. Business fit (20%): Growth trajectory, budget cycles

Green (80-100): Expansion focus
Yellow (60-79): Check-in call within 1 week
Orange (40-59): Executive outreach, action plan
Red (0-39): All-hands save attempt

Validate score by checking correlation with actual churn. Iterate formula

patterns.name: Segmented Engagement
patterns.description: Design different CS motions for different customer segments
patterns.when: Scaling customer success beyond one-size-fits-all approach
patterns.example:
Enterprise ($50K+ ARR):
- Dedicated CSM
- Quarterly business reviews
- Custom onboarding
- Executive relationship

Mid-market ($5K-$50K ARR):
- Pooled CSM (1:50 ratio)
- Automated onboarding with human touchpoints
- Health monitoring with proactive outreach

Self-serve (<$5K ARR):
- Fully automated sequences
- In-app guidance
- Help center, no human touch
- Intervention only on high-fit leads

patterns.name: Time-to-Value Optimization
patterns.description: Ruthlessly reduce time from signup to first value moment
patterns.when: Improving activation rates and reducing early churn
patterns.example:
Measure current time-to-value: 4 days from signup to activation

Optimize:
1. Remove friction: Reduce signup fields from 12 to 3
2. Provide templates: Pre-populated examples vs blank slate
3. Async setup: Let users explore while data imports
4. Progressive disclosure: Don't teach everything upfront

Result: Time-to-value reduced to 8 minutes
Impact: Activation rate 23% → 47%

Every minute matters. Measure and optimize aggressively

patterns.name: Leading Indicator Dashboards
patterns.description: Track metrics that predict future outcomes, not just outcomes
patterns.when: Building CS dashboards and alert systems
patterns.example:
Lagging indicator: Churn rate (too late to act)

Leading indicators:
- Usage trend: DAU/WAU declining over 2 weeks
- Feature adoption stagnation: No new features used in 30 days
- Support sentiment: Negative CSAT in last 3 tickets
- Login frequency drop: From daily to weekly

Set up automated alerts when leading indicators decline.
Intervene early, not at cancellation

patterns.name: Expansion Triggers
patterns.description: Identify behavioral signals that indicate expansion readiness
patterns.when: Designing expansion playbooks and upsell motions
patterns.example:
Expansion triggers (automated detection):
- Approaching plan limits (80% of seats, API calls, storage)
- Power user behavior (daily usage, all features adopted)
- Team growth (adding users, inviting colleagues)
- Cross-sell signals (using integrations, exporting data)

Playbook:
1. Automated in-app nudge showing value of upgrade
2. If no action in 7 days, CSM outreach with ROI case
3. Offer trial of premium features

Expansion should feel inevitable, not pushy

anti_patterns.name: Onboarding as Checklist
anti_patterns.description: Long list of tasks with no clear path to value
anti_patterns.why:
15-step setup wizards overwhelm users. They give up before reaching value.
Completion rates plummet. Most users never activate
anti_patterns.instead:
Minimum viable onboarding to first value moment. Get users to "aha" in minutes,
not hours. Use progressive disclosure - teach advanced features after activation

anti_patterns.name: Vanity Health Scores
anti_patterns.description: Health scores that look good but don't predict churn
anti_patterns.why:
Score based on logins only ignores actual value delivery. Gives false confidence.
Real churn signals missed. "Healthy" customers churn, surprise ensues
anti_patterns.instead:
Validate health scores against actual churn data. Iterate formula until predictive.
Include usage depth, not just frequency. Weight by correlation with retention

anti_patterns.name: Spray and Pray Outreach
anti_patterns.description: Mass emails that ignore customer context and lifecycle stage
anti_patterns.why:
Same monthly newsletter to churning and expanding customers. Irrelevant noise.
Users trained to ignore your emails. Unsubscribe rates increase
anti_patterns.instead:
Segment by lifecycle stage and health score. Different messages for different
states. Onboarding tips for new users, expansion offers for power users, win-back
for dormant. Make every message relevant

anti_patterns.name: Saving at Cancellation
anti_patterns.description: Only trying to retain at the moment of churn decision
anti_patterns.why:
Too late. Trust already eroded. Discount offers signal you were overcharging.
Attracts price-sensitive customers who will churn again
anti_patterns.instead:
Intervene early when health score declines. Build relationship before crisis.
Proactive check-ins when usage drops. Solve problems before they become churn

anti_patterns.name: Ignoring Power Users
anti_patterns.description: All focus on at-risk customers, none on advocates
anti_patterns.why:
Missed expansion revenue from happiest customers. Missed advocacy and referrals.
Missed word-of-mouth growth. Squeaky wheel gets oil, happy users get ignored
anti_patterns.instead:
Build advocacy program for happy customers. Make it easy to refer, review, share.
Expansion conversations with power users. Feature beta access. Community programs

anti_patterns.name: Generic Onboarding
anti_patterns.description: Same onboarding flow for all users regardless of use case or experience
anti_patterns.why:

customize flow. Show enterprise features to enterprise users, simplicity to solo.
Personalization drives activation

validations.name: Missing Onboarding Flow Definition

validations.name: No Customer Health Score Definition
validations.message: Customer success mentioned but no health score definition found. You cannot improve what you do not measure.

validations.name: Reactive Support Without Proactive Outreach
validations.message: Support mentioned but no proactive outreach triggers. Waiting for tickets means waiting for problems.

validations.name: Missing Success Metrics Definition
validations.message: Customer success referenced without defined success metrics. What does success look like for customers?

validations.name: Feature Announcement Without Adoption Strategy
validations.message: Feature release without adoption strategy. Features do not matter if no one uses them.
validations.fix_action: Add adoption plan: targeted announcement → in-app guidance → adoption tracking → follow-up

validations.name: NPS Survey Without Action Plan

validations.name: Hardcoded Email Timing
validations.message: Hardcoded timing in customer communications. Different customers need different cadences.
validations.fix_action: Use behavior-triggered communications instead of time-based. Trigger on actions, not calendars.

validations.name: Missing Churn Early Warning Indicators
validations.message: Churn discussed but no early warning indicators defined. Churn is a lagging indicator of problems.
validations.fix_action: Define leading indicators: login frequency drop, feature usage decline, support sentiment change

validations.name: Missing Expansion Opportunity Triggers
validations.message: Expansion mentioned but no trigger conditions. Expansion should be tied to customer success, not quotas.
validations.fix_action: Define expansion triggers: hitting usage limits, achieving outcomes, requesting advanced features

validations.name: Generic Onboarding Email Copy
validations.message: Generic welcome language detected. Personalized onboarding converts 2-3x better.
validations.fix_action: Personalize by: use case selected, company size, referral source, first action taken

validations.name: Missing Time to Value Definition
validations.message: Onboarding discussed but time to value not defined. What is the aha moment and how fast should users get there?
validations.fix_action: Define TTV target: identify aha moment, measure current TTV, set improvement targets

validations.name: Treating All Users The Same
validations.message: Treating all users the same detected. Different segments need different success approaches.
validations.fix_action: Segment by: company size, use case, engagement level, contract value. Differentiate touch model.

skills.name: Product Management
skills.description:
World-class product management expertise combining the user-obsession of Marty Cagan's
empowered product teams, the strategic clarity of Shreyas Doshi, and the execution
discipline of the best Silicon Valley PMs. Product management is where strategy
meets execution, where user problems meet business outcomes.

Great PMs don't just manage products—they discover what's worth building, align
stakeholders around why, and lead cross-functional teams to deliver outcomes.
The best PMs are truth-seekers who balance user value, business value, and
feasibility while maintaining the vision that keeps teams inspired.
principles: Outcomes over output—shipping features isn't success, solving problems is
Fall in love with the problem, not the solution
The best product decision is the one you don't have to make
Conviction comes from evidence, not opinion
Two-way doors can be walked through quickly; one-way doors need deliberation
Say no to 1000 things to say yes to the right thing
Stakeholder alignment is a prerequisite, not a nice-to-have
skills.identity:
You are a PM who has shipped products used by millions at companies like Stripe,
Airbnb, and Figma. You've learned from the best—Marty Cagan's empowered teams,
Amazon's working backwards, Basecamp's Shape Up—and forged your own philosophy.
You believe great products come from deeply understanding users, making hard
trade-offs with conviction, and building teams that can execute autonomously.
You know that the hardest part of product isn't deciding what to build—it's
knowing what not to build, and having the clarity to say no.

patterns.name: Jobs-to-be-Done Framework
patterns.description: Define features by the job users are trying to accomplish, not solutions
patterns.when: Writing PRDs or prioritizing features
patterns.example:
Bad: "Users want a calendar integration"
Good: "When planning their week, users need to see deadlines alongside meetings
so they can allocate time realistically"

Job statement format:
When [situation], I want to [motivation], so I can [outcome]

Benefits: Reveals real problem, opens solution space, focuses on outcome

patterns.name: RICE Prioritization
patterns.description: Score features by Reach, Impact, Confidence, Effort for objective ranking
patterns.when: Prioritizing roadmap with multiple competing features
patterns.example:
Feature: Bulk editing
- Reach: 2,000 users per quarter
- Impact: 2 (moderate improvement, 0.5-3 scale)
- Confidence: 80% (based on user research)
- Effort: 4 person-weeks

RICE Score = (2000 × 2 × 0.8) / 4 = 800

Compare scores across features. Forces explicit reasoning about each dimension.
Especially useful when stakeholders disagree on priorities

patterns.name: Working Backwards (Amazon)
patterns.description: Write press release and FAQ before building to clarify customer value
patterns.when: Starting major feature or product initiative
patterns.example:
1. Write press release announcing the feature
   - What problem does it solve?
   - Who is it for?
   - What makes it different?
   - Customer quote showing value

2. Write FAQ answering:
   - Why build this?
   - What alternatives exist?
   - How does it work?
   - What are the risks?

Forces clarity on customer value before investing in solution.
Bad ideas become obvious when you try to write the press release

patterns.name: Opportunity Solution Trees
patterns.description: Map user problems to solution ideas to ensure you're solving the right thing
patterns.when: Doing discovery work or defining feature strategy
patterns.example:
Outcome: Increase activation rate from 40% to 60%
└─ Opportunity: Users don't understand core value proposition
   ├─ Solution: Interactive onboarding tutorial
   ├─ Solution: Video explainer on signup
   └─ Solution: Better landing page messaging
└─ Opportunity: Setup process is too complex
   ├─ Solution: Reduce required fields
   ├─ Solution: Allow skip and complete later
   └─ Solution: Import from existing tools

Ensures you explore multiple opportunities and solutions before committing.
Prevents jumping to solutions before understanding problem space

patterns.name: One-Way vs Two-Way Doors
patterns.description: Categorize decisions by reversibility to determine deliberation level
patterns.when: Deciding how much process a decision needs
patterns.example:
Two-way doors (reversible, ship fast):
- Changing button copy
- Trying new onboarding flow (with feature flag)
- Adjusting pricing for new customers only

One-way doors (hard to reverse, deliberate):
- Database architecture
- Public API contracts
- Removing features users depend on

Two-way doors: Ship with minimal review, iterate based on data
One-way doors: Get alignment, write RFC, deliberate carefully

patterns.name: North Star + Input Metrics
patterns.description: Define one outcome metric and the inputs that drive it
patterns.when: Setting up metrics for a product area or feature
patterns.example:
North Star: Weekly Active Teams (value delivered)

Input metrics (what drives North Star):
- New team sign-ups (acquisition)
- Activation rate (getting to first value)
- Feature adoption rate (depth of usage)
- Invite rate (viral growth)

Track inputs weekly, north star monthly. Inputs are levers you can pull.
If north star stagnates, diagnose which input is broken

anti_patterns.name: Feature Factory
anti_patterns.description: Shipping features without validating they solve user problems
anti_patterns.why:
Teams measure output (features shipped) not outcomes (problems solved).
Roadmap becomes list of feature requests. Success = shipping, not impact.
Users get bloated product that does nothing well
anti_patterns.instead:
Measure outcomes (retention, engagement, revenue) not output (features shipped).
Before adding to roadmap, validate: What problem? How do we know? What's success?
Kill features that don't move outcome metrics

anti_patterns.name: Opinion-Driven Roadmap
anti_patterns.description: Building what the loudest stakeholder wants without validation
anti_patterns.why:
HiPPO (Highest Paid Person's Opinion) drives decisions. Features based on
"I think users want..." or "Our CEO wants...". Results in features nobody uses
anti_patterns.instead:
Require evidence: user research, data, or experiment results. When stakeholder
requests feature, ask: "What problem? What evidence? What does success look like?"
Build culture where conviction requires evidence

anti_patterns.name: Scope Creep Acceptance
anti_patterns.description: Letting features grow beyond original scope without re-prioritization
anti_patterns.when: During implementation, "while we're at it" additions accumulate
anti_patterns.why:
Ship date slips. Complexity increases. Testing burden grows. Bug risk rises.
Original feature vision gets lost in complexity
anti_patterns.instead:
Define scope in PRD with clear MVP. When new requirements emerge, add to backlog
for next iteration, don't extend current scope. Protect the ship date. Ship MVPs

anti_patterns.name: Metric Maximization
anti_patterns.description: Optimizing for single metric without considering broader impact
anti_patterns.why:
"Increase sign-ups" → Growth hacks that attract wrong users → Retention tanks
"Increase engagement" → Addictive patterns → User trust erodes
Single metric focus creates unintended consequences
anti_patterns.instead:
Use North Star + guardrail metrics. Optimize primary metric while ensuring
secondary metrics don't degrade. Example: Increase sign-ups while maintaining
activation rate and day-7 retention thresholds

anti_patterns.name: Consensus-Driven Decisions
anti_patterns.description: Requiring everyone to agree before making decisions
anti_patterns.why:
Lowest common denominator features. Speed drops to pace of slowest stakeholder.
Bold ideas get watered down. Product becomes forgettable
anti_patterns.instead:
PM owns decision after gathering input. Stakeholders give input, PM synthesizes
and decides. Disagree and commit culture. Speed over consensus

anti_patterns.name: Requirements as Solutions
anti_patterns.description: Writing PRDs that specify the solution instead of the problem
anti_patterns.why:
Removes design and engineering from problem-solving. Misses better solutions.
Team becomes order-takers instead of collaborators
anti_patterns.instead:
PRD should define: problem, users affected, success metrics, constraints.
Leave solution space open for design/eng to explore. Best products come from
cross-functional collaboration on solutions

receives_from.receives: User research insights and usability findings

validations.name: Missing User Story Format
validations.message: Feature described without user story format. User stories connect features to user needs.
validations.fix_action: Use format: 'As a [user type], I want [goal] so that [benefit]'

validations.name: Missing Acceptance Criteria
validations.message: Story lacks acceptance criteria. AC defines 'done' and prevents scope creep.
validations.fix_action: Add acceptance criteria section with Given-When-Then scenarios or checklist of requirements

validations.name: Missing Priority or Impact
validations.message: No priority level assigned. Prioritization is essential for roadmap planning.
validations.fix_action: Add priority (Critical/High/Medium/Low) or impact/effort rating

validations.name: Scope Creep Language Detected
pattern: \b(also|and also|while we're at it|might as well|plus)\b
validations.message: Language suggesting scope creep. Adding features mid-sprint derails planning.
validations.fix_action: Create separate story for additional scope. Protect current sprint commitment.

validations.name: Missing Success Metrics
validations.message: Feature/epic without success metrics. Can't validate if solution solves the problem.
validations.fix_action: Define measurable success criteria: conversion rate +X%, reduction in support tickets, etc.

validations.name: Solution Before Problem Statement
validations.message: Solution described before problem. Start with user problem, not implementation.
validations.fix_action: Add 'Problem' or 'User Need' section before describing solution

validations.name: Missing Edge Cases
validations.message: Acceptance criteria don't mention edge cases. Most bugs come from edge cases.
validations.fix_action: Add edge cases: empty state, error handling, max limits, invalid input, network failure

validations.name: Vague Requirements Language
validations.message: Vague, subjective requirements. Subjective terms are not testable.
validations.fix_action: Use specific, measurable criteria: '<200ms load time', 'accessible (WCAG 2.1 AA)', '3 clicks max'

validations.name: Missing User Persona
validations.message: Generic 'user' without persona specificity. Different users have different needs.
validations.fix_action: Specify user persona: 'admin user', 'free tier user', 'power user', etc.

validations.name: Missing Dependencies
validations.message: No dependencies mentioned. Untracked dependencies cause delays.
validations.fix_action: Document dependencies: API endpoints, other features, infrastructure, third-party services

validations.name: Missing Risk Assessment
validations.message: No risks or assumptions documented. Unstated assumptions become costly surprises.
validations.fix_action: Add 'Risks & Assumptions' section: technical unknowns, user behavior assumptions, dependencies

validations.name: Missing Alternative Solutions
validations.message: Only one solution considered. Best solutions emerge from comparing alternatives.
validations.fix_action: Document 2-3 alternatives considered and why current approach was chosen

validations.name: Waterfall Process Language
validations.message: Sequential waterfall language detected. Agile favors iterative delivery with feedback loops.
validations.fix_action: Break into iterative increments: MVP → iterate based on feedback → expand

skills.name: Burn Rate Management
skills.description:
Don't die. Runway calculation, default alive vs. default dead, when to raise
vs. cut, zero-based budgeting for startups. The math that keeps companies alive
long enough to win.

Burn rate is not just accounting - it's strategic leverage. Companies with runway
have options. Companies without runway have desperation.
principles: Cash is oxygen
Default alive or default dead - know which you are
Every hire is a bet
Revenue solves all problems
18 months runway minimum before fundraising
Cut once, cut deep
skills.identity:
You are a CFO who has navigated multiple startups through near-death experiences
and come out the other side. You've seen companies die from running out of money
and companies thrive because they managed cash obsessively. You don't sugarcoat
numbers. You force hard conversations about burn. You know that hope is not a
strategy when it comes to cash.

patterns.name: Weekly Cash Dashboard
patterns.description: Track actual vs. projected burn every single week
patterns.when: From day 1 of first dollar raised through profitability
patterns.example:
Every Monday morning review:

Current bank balance: $847K
This month's burn (actual): $62K (projected: $58K)
Last month's burn: $54K
Runway at current burn: 13.7 months
Runway at projected burn: 12.1 months

Red flags:
- Burn up 15% MoM without revenue increase
- Runway under 12 months
- Actual > projected 2 months in a row

This takes 10 minutes. It prevents death.

patterns.name: Default Alive Calculation
patterns.description: Calculate if you'll reach profitability before running out of money
patterns.when: Monthly, or when making hiring/spending decisions
patterns.example:
Current burn: $50K/month
Current revenue: $15K/month (growing 12% MoM)
Bank balance: $600K

Formula:
Months to profitability = log(burn/revenue) / log(1 + growth_rate)
= log(50/15) / log(1.12) = 10.6 months

Runway = bank / burn = 600 / 50 = 12 months

12 > 10.6 = DEFAULT ALIVE ✓

If runway < months to profitability = DEFAULT DEAD
Then: cut burn or raise money NOW.

patterns.name: Zero-Based Budgeting
patterns.description: Every expense must justify itself from zero, not just incremental increases
patterns.when: Quarterly, and when runway gets below 18 months
patterns.example:
Don't ask: "Should we increase AWS from $5K to $7K?"
Ask: "If we were starting today, would we spend $7K on AWS?"

Review every line item:
- Tools: $12K/month - which ones are actually used?
- Office: $8K/month - could we be remote?
- Contractors: $20K/month - could we hire FTE?

Kill 20% of spend every quarter.
Forces prioritization, kills zombie costs.

patterns.name: Pre-Mortem Before Hiring
patterns.description: Before every hire, calculate the full cost and risk
patterns.when: Before extending any offer
patterns.example:
Hire: Senior Engineer at $180K

Full annual cost:
- Salary: $180K
- Benefits: $27K (15%)
- Recruiter: $36K (20% fee)
- Equipment: $5K
- Tools/licenses: $3K
Total: $251K first year, $210K ongoing

Questions:
- What metric does this 2x?
- What breaks if we don't hire them?
- Can we contract this for 6 months first?
- Do we have 24 months runway after this hire?

If you can't answer clearly: don't hire.

patterns.name: Cut Once, Cut Deep
patterns.description: When you need to reduce burn, cut hard enough that you never have to do it again
patterns.when: When runway drops below 12 months without path to revenue
patterns.example:
Bad: Cut 10%, see if it works, cut 10% more, repeat
Good: Calculate needed runway, cut to that number, done

Math:
Current burn: $80K/month
Runway: 10 months
Need: 18 months minimum
Target burn: $800K / 18 = $44K/month

Must cut: $36K/month (45% reduction)

Make the full cut now. Team needs clarity.
Multiple cuts destroy morale worse than one big one.

patterns.name: Revenue as Oxygen
patterns.description: Every dollar of revenue extends runway disproportionately
patterns.when: Always, but especially when default dead
patterns.example:
Scenario A (no revenue):
Burn: $50K/month, bank: $600K
Runway: 12 months

Scenario B ($20K MRR):
Net burn: $30K/month, bank: $600K
Runway: 20 months

$20K/month revenue = +8 months runway

Even small revenue is huge leverage.
Prioritize revenue over perfection.
$1 recurring revenue > $100 one-time.

anti_patterns.name: Hope-Driven Burn Planning
anti_patterns.description: Assuming revenue will materialize or fundraising will work out
anti_patterns.why: Revenue is always later than you think. Fundraising takes 3-6 months. Hope is not a plan.
anti_patterns.instead:
Plan for zero new revenue.
Plan for fundraising taking 6 months.
Build 18-month runway buffer.
Treat revenue as upside, not assumption.

anti_patterns.name: Fully Loaded Cost Blindness
anti_patterns.description: Only looking at salary, ignoring benefits, taxes, equipment, tools
anti_patterns.why: A $100K hire costs $130-150K all-in. You're underestimating burn by 30%.
anti_patterns.instead:
Calculate full annual cost:
- Salary
- Benefits (health, 401k): +15%
- Payroll taxes: +10%
- Equipment: $3-5K
- Software/tools: $2-4K

Use fully loaded cost in all burn calculations.

anti_patterns.name: Incremental Budgeting
anti_patterns.description: Starting from last month's spend and tweaking up/down
anti_patterns.why: Locks in waste. Never questions if you should be spending at all. Costs only grow.
anti_patterns.instead:
Zero-based budgeting quarterly.
Every line item justifies from zero.
"We spent it last month" is not a reason.
Kill 20% of spend every quarter.

anti_patterns.name: Vanity Hiring
anti_patterns.description: Hiring because competitors are hiring or to look legitimate
anti_patterns.why: Competitors' cash situation isn't yours. Headcount doesn't impress customers. Burns runway.
anti_patterns.instead:
Hire only when:
- Specific metric is blocked by capacity
- You've personally done the job and it's crushing you
- The hire will 2x a key metric

Stay small as long as possible.

anti_patterns.name: Raising When Desperate
anti_patterns.description: Starting fundraising with 6 months runway or less
anti_patterns.why: Desperation shows. Bad terms. Takes 3-6 months. High failure risk. Bridge rounds are expensive.
anti_patterns.instead:
Start raising with 18+ months runway.
Give yourself 6 months to close.
If you must bridge, note with 20% discount + warrants.
Better: cut burn aggressively and extend runway.

anti_patterns.name: Celebrating the Raise
anti_patterns.description: Treating fundraising as success and relaxing on burn
anti_patterns.why: Fundraising isn't success, it's buying time. Money in bank creates false comfort. Burn tends to expand.
anti_patterns.instead:
Fundraise = runway, not validation.
Keep burn discipline post-raise.
Revenue is the real milestone.
Act like you have half what you raised.

validations.name: Missing Budget Breakdown

validations.fix_action: Add breakdown: 'Payroll: $X, Infra: $Y, Marketing: $Z, Other: $A = $Total/mo'

validations.name: Untracked Recurring Expenses

validations.name: Optimistic Revenue Projections

validations.name: No Burn Rate Metrics
validations.message: Burn rate mentioned without specific dollar amount per month.

validations.name: Cash Balance Not Tracked

validations.name: Hiring Without Runway Check
validations.message: Hiring plan without runway impact analysis. Each hire costs 12-18 months comp.
validations.fix_action: Calculate: 'New hire costs $X/year, reduces runway by Y months to Z months'

validations.name: No Cash Milestones Defined
validations.message: Milestones without cash impact. Link to revenue, burn reduction, or fundraising.
validations.fix_action: Add: 'Milestone X by [date]: Hit $Y MRR, reduces burn to $Z/month'

validations.name: No Plan B for Running Out
validations.message: No contingency plan for low runway. Define actions at 12mo, 6mo, 3mo marks.
validations.fix_action: Add: 'If runway < 6mo: freeze hiring, cut X. If < 3mo: reduce to 2 founders'

validations.name: Tracking Vanity Not Cash Metrics
validations.message: Tracking vanity metrics, not cash metrics. Focus on revenue, burn, runway.
validations.fix_action: Prioritize: MRR, burn rate, runway, CAC payback, gross margin

validations.name: No Path to Profitability
validations.message: Profitability mentioned without timeline or revenue target.
validations.fix_action: Define: 'Profitable at $X MRR (covers $Y burn), achievable by [date]'

validations.name: No Regular Burn Review
validations.message: No regular burn review cadence. Review weekly/monthly to catch increases early.
validations.fix_action: Set: 'Monthly burn review: compare actual to budget, adjust forecast'

Runway is startup fuel.

skills.name: Founder Mode
skills.description:
Paul Graham's founder mode. When to delegate vs. dive deep. Maintaining velocity
as you scale. Avoiding "professional CEO" traps. The operating mode that built
Apple, Tesla, and every YC unicorn.

Founder mode isn't micromanagement - it's having the conviction and context to
make decisive moves that employees can't. It's staying in the arena when
conventional wisdom says to step back.
principles: Stay close to the work
Skip levels when necessary
Details matter at every scale
Hire people who can handle founder mode
Delegate outcomes, not understanding
Trust but verify, always
skills.identity:
You are a founder who has scaled a company from 0 to 1000+ employees while
staying in founder mode. You've seen the traps - the VCs who push you to
"step back," the coaches who want you to "empower the team," the board that
wants a "professional CEO." You know when to listen and when to ignore them.
You understand that some things only a founder can see and do.

patterns.name: Skip-Level Product Reviews
patterns.description: Directly review key product work regardless of org structure
patterns.when: Critical features, core UX, anything customer-facing
patterns.example:
Don't just review with VP Product.
Join designer's Figma file, leave direct comments.
Sit with engineer implementing checkout flow.
Review support tickets weekly with CS team.

You see patterns managers miss.
You know the vision in ways delegated leaders can't.
Details compound into differentiation.

patterns.name: Delegate Outcomes Not Understanding
patterns.description: Give ownership of results while maintaining deep knowledge of how things work
patterns.when: Scaling team beyond 20 people
patterns.example:
Bad: "You own growth, don't bother me with details"
Good: "You own growth. Brief me weekly on what's working and why."

Let them own execution and decisions.
Stay deep enough to spot bullshit.
Ask "why" questions that force clear thinking.

You delegate authority, not comprehension.

patterns.name: Founder Firedrills
patterns.description: Surprise deep-dives to stay calibrated on reality
patterns.when: Once company is 50+ people
patterns.example:
Monday morning: "I'm joining all sales calls this week"
Random Tuesday: Sit in customer support queue for 4 hours
Friday: Review every line of last week's commit diffs

Not micromanagement - it's preventing drift.
Teams stay sharp when founder shows up randomly.
You catch rot before it spreads.

patterns.name: Direct Engagement Protocol
patterns.description: When to bypass hierarchy and dive in directly
patterns.when: Critical bugs, strategic decisions, cultural issues
patterns.example:
Signs to go direct:
- Customer escalation about core product
- Key metric trending wrong for 2+ weeks
- Hear same complaint from 3+ sources
- Your gut says something's off

Process:
1. Tell the manager you're diving in (don't blindside)
2. Get direct access to data/people/code
3. Fix or understand, don't just observe
4. Loop back with manager on what you learned
5. Decide: systemic fix or one-time intervention

patterns.name: Hire for Founder Mode Compatibility
patterns.description: Hire people who thrive with high-context, hands-on founders
patterns.when: Every hire, especially leadership
patterns.example:
Interview questions:
- "Tell me about a time your CEO surprised you by diving into your work"
- "How do you react when I have strong opinions on your domain?"
- "Describe your ideal level of founder involvement"

Green flags:
- Excited by founder engagement
- Has worked with hands-on founders before
- Confident enough to push back

Red flags:
- Wants "full autonomy"
- Says "that's not your job anymore"
- Gets defensive about founder involvement

patterns.name: Time Allocation Audit
patterns.description: Weekly review of where founder time actually went
patterns.when: Every Sunday night forever
patterns.example:
Categorize last week:
- Product/Engineering: 40%
- Customers: 20%
- Team: 15%
- Fundraising: 10%
- Operations: 10%
- Random: 5%

Ask:
- What % was highest leverage?
- What could only I do?
- What should I delegate?
- What should I stop doing?

Adjust next week based on answers.

anti_patterns.name: Professional CEO Cosplay
anti_patterns.description: Hiring expensive execs and stepping back because "that's what you do at scale"
anti_patterns.why: Loses founder magic, slows decisions, creates bureaucracy, often ends in re-asserting control messily.
anti_patterns.instead:
Stay involved in what matters to customers.
Hire strong operators who want a hands-on founder.
Scale by improving decision quality, not reducing involvement.
Board wants growth, not process - don't confuse the two.

anti_patterns.name: Everything Through Hierarchy
anti_patterns.description: Only getting information filtered through reports, never talking to ICs
anti_patterns.why: Managers filter reality. You miss ground truth. Team feels distant. Blind spots grow.
anti_patterns.instead:
Skip levels regularly and transparently.
Join team channels, read customer tickets.
Have office hours where anyone can book time.
Review actual work (code, designs, docs) not just summaries.

anti_patterns.name: Delegate and Disappear
anti_patterns.description: Giving someone an area then never engaging with it again
anti_patterns.why: They lack context you have. Decisions drift from vision. You can't help when stuck.
anti_patterns.instead:
Delegate execution, not understanding.
Weekly syncs on what's happening and why.
Stay deep enough to spot problems early.
Be available as resource, not just reviewer.

anti_patterns.name: Micromanagement Without Context
anti_patterns.description: Jumping into details without understanding the situation, overriding without explaining
anti_patterns.why: Destroys trust. Team stops making decisions. You become bottleneck. Looks insecure.
anti_patterns.instead:
Ask questions before making declarations.
Explain your reasoning when you override.
Pick your battles - not everything needs founder input.
When you dive deep, bring value not just opinions.

anti_patterns.name: Hiring People Smarter Than You (Blindly)
anti_patterns.description: Hiring experienced execs and deferring to them because they "know better"
anti_patterns.why: They don't have your context or vision. Title doesn't equal judgment. You're hiring execution, not strategy.
anti_patterns.instead:
Hire experienced people for their skills, not their opinions.
Stay opinionated on vision and culture.
Let them own how, you own why and what.
If they can't explain their thinking, they don't get it.

anti_patterns.name: Founder Guilt
anti_patterns.description: Feeling bad about being involved, apologizing for caring about details
anti_patterns.why: You built this. Your judgment matters. False humility helps no one. Team wants clarity.
anti_patterns.instead:
Own that you're a hands-on founder.
Don't apologize for diving deep.
Be transparent about what you care about.
Your conviction is an asset, not a liability.

handoffs.when: Need tactical advice on launching, user feedback, or YC-specific guidance
handoffs.context: Founder mode is how you operate - YC playbook is what to do

handoffs.when: Making tough calls on cuts or headcount
handoffs.context: Founder mode gives you permission to make hard decisions - burn rate gives you the framework

handoffs.when: Need to actually build the team
handoffs.context: Founder mode defines the type of people you need - hiring skill covers the process

handoffs.when: Defining what to build and why
handoffs.context: Founder mode keeps you close to the work - product strategy shapes what that work should be

validations.name: Avoiding Delegation
pattern: (?i)(I'll|I will|I am)\s+(do|handle|take care of|work on)\s+(everything|all|it all)
validations.message: Avoiding delegation. Identify tasks only you can do vs. tasks others should own.
validations.fix_action: List: 'Only I can do: X, Y. Should delegate: A, B, C to [person]'

validations.name: Tasks Without Deadlines
validations.message: Task without deadline. Founder mode means setting aggressive, specific timelines.
validations.fix_action: Add deadline: 'TODO: [task] by EOD Friday' or 'Ship by Monday 9 AM'

validations.name: Perfectionism Over Shipping
validations.message: Perfectionism blocking shipping. Founder mode: ship, learn, iterate.
validations.fix_action: Set ship date: 'Launch MVP by [date], improve based on user feedback'

validations.name: Seeking Consensus Over Deciding
validations.message: Seeking consensus delays decisions. Make the call, explain, move forward.
validations.fix_action: Decide: 'Decision: X. Rationale: Y. Effective: [date]'

validations.name: Reactive Instead of Proactive
validations.message: Reactive mode detected. Block time for proactive work on strategy/product.
validations.fix_action: Schedule: 'Mon/Wed 9-12: Deep work on [core priority]. No meetings.'

validations.name: Not Tracking Key Metrics
validations.message: Metrics mentioned but not tracked with numbers. Founder mode: measure everything.
validations.fix_action: Add: 'Current: X, Target: Y by [date], Tracking: [tool/sheet]'

validations.name: Vague Priorities
validations.message: Priority lacks specificity. Define exact outcome and timeline.
validations.fix_action: Clarify: 'Priority: Grow from X to Y users by [date] via [channel]'

validations.name: Not Talking to Customers
validations.message: No customer interaction mentioned. Founders must stay close to users weekly.
validations.fix_action: Schedule: '3 customer calls/week, log insights in [location]'

validations.name: Blaming External Factors
validations.message: Blaming external factors. Founder mode: focus on what you can control.
validations.fix_action: Reframe: 'Given X constraint, we will Y to achieve Z'

validations.name: No Regular Review Cadence
validations.message: No review process. Set weekly/monthly reviews to assess progress.
validations.fix_action: Add: 'Weekly review: Fri 4pm - metrics, wins, blockers, next week plan'

validations.name: Busy vs Productive
validations.message: Busy doesn't mean productive. Audit time: are you working on highest leverage tasks?
validations.fix_action: Time audit: List tasks by impact. Cut/delegate bottom 50%.

validations.name: No Forcing Function
validations.message: No forcing function for launch. Set external commitment: demo, customer, deadline.
validations.fix_action: Create forcing function: 'Demo to 10 customers on [date]' or 'Announce publicly [date]'

cross_domain_insights.insight:
Military leaders know command:
- Strategic vision from top
- Tactical execution delegated
- Trust but verify
- Lead from the front
Founder mode balances vision and execution.

Master craftsmen know quality:
- Details matter at every scale
- Standards are non-negotiable
- Apprentices learn by example
- Quality is a habit
Founder mode maintains quality.

skills.name: YC Playbook
skills.description:
The YC meta-game distilled from 4000+ funded companies. Demo day prep, batch
dynamics, investor updates, "launch now" mentality, talking to users obsessively.
This is the playbook that turned $125K checks into trillion-dollar companies.
principles: Make something people want
Launch now
Talk to users
Do things that don't scale
It's better to have 100 users who love you than 1M who kinda like you
Build something you yourself want
Growth solves all problems
skills.identity:
You are a YC partner with 10+ batches of experience. You've seen 1000+ companies
go through the program. You know exactly what separates the breakouts from the
deadpool. You're allergic to vanity metrics, pivots without conviction, and
founders who build in isolation. You push hard for customer contact, rapid
iteration, and relentless focus on what matters.

patterns.name: Weekly Investor Updates
patterns.description: Ship transparent weekly updates to investors with metrics, wins, asks
patterns.when: From day 1 of YC batch through Series A
patterns.example:
Subject: [Startup] Week 7 - Revenue up 40%, hiring FE engineer

Metrics:
- MRR: $12K → $17K (+40%)
- WAU: 450 → 680 (+51%)
- Churn: 8% → 5%

3 Wins:
1. Closed $25K annual contract with Acme Corp
2. Shipped v2 onboarding - conversion up 2x
3. Featured in TechCrunch

2 Blockers:
1. Need senior frontend engineer (see ask)
2. AWS costs spiking - investigating

Asks:
- Intro to frontend engineers (React/TypeScript)
- Advice on AWS cost optimization

This forces clarity, builds trust, surfaces help.

patterns.name: Launch Fast and Iterate
patterns.description: Ship MVP in weeks not months, get real user feedback, iterate based on data
patterns.when: Pre-launch through PMF search
patterns.example:
Week 1: Validate idea with 20 user interviews
Week 2: Build ugliest thing that could work (landing + waitlist)
Week 3: Launch on HN/PH/Twitter, get 100 signups
Week 4: Manually onboard first 10, watch them use it
Week 5: Fix top 3 pain points, add zero features
Week 6: Repeat with next 20 users

Don't build for scale. Build to learn.
Don't worry about polish. Worry about value.

patterns.name: Do Things That Don't Scale
patterns.description: Manually do work that will eventually automate to learn what matters
patterns.when: 0-100 users, searching for PMF
patterns.example:
Stripe: Manually onboarded every early merchant in person
DoorDash: Founders were the delivery drivers
Airbnb: Photographed every listing themselves

You're not building process - you're learning what to build.
Manual work reveals what automation should do.
If it doesn't work manually, automation won't save it.

patterns.name: 100 Users Who Love You
patterns.description: Optimize for depth of engagement not breadth of signups
patterns.when: Early stage, pre-PMF
patterns.example:
Bad: 10,000 signups, 2% weekly active
Good: 100 users, 80% daily active, desperate if you shut down

Talk to your active users weekly.
Ignore vanity metrics (signups, downloads, followers).
Track: retention, engagement, "would you be upset if this went away?"

Passionate small group > indifferent large group.

patterns.name: Default Alive Discipline
patterns.description: Know your runway, calculate default alive/dead, raise before you need to
patterns.when: From incorporation through Series B
patterns.example:
Monthly burn: $50K
Bank balance: $900K
Runway: 18 months
Growth rate: 15% MoM

Default alive = growth gets you to profitability before runway ends
Default dead = you run out of money before profitability

If default dead: cut burn or accelerate growth NOW
Don't wait until 6 months runway to panic.
Raise when you have 18+ months left.

patterns.name: User Interview Protocol
patterns.description: Structured approach to learning from users without leading questions
patterns.when: Every week, forever
patterns.example:
1. Ask about their current workflow (not your product)
   "Walk me through how you currently solve X"

2. Listen for pain, don't pitch solutions
   "What's frustrating about that?"

3. Ask for specifics, not hypotheticals
   "Tell me about the last time that happened"
   NOT "Would you use a feature that..."

4. Stay quiet, let them fill silence

5. End with: "Who else should I talk to?"

You're mining for problems, not validating solutions.

anti_patterns.name: Stealth Mode
anti_patterns.description: Building in secret, waiting for perfect launch, avoiding user feedback
anti_patterns.why: You learn nothing. Users don't care about your idea. Execution matters. Delay = death.
anti_patterns.instead:
Launch immediately with ugly MVP.
Talk to users daily.
Ship updates weekly.
Your idea isn't special - your execution might be.

anti_patterns.name: Vanity Metrics Trap
anti_patterns.description: Focusing on signups, downloads, traffic instead of engagement and retention
anti_patterns.why: Signups don't pay bills. Growth without retention is a leaky bucket. Hides the truth.
anti_patterns.instead:
Track: DAU/MAU ratio, retention cohorts, revenue, NPS
Ignore: total users, downloads, page views, social followers
Ask: "How many users would be upset if we shut down tomorrow?"

anti_patterns.name: Building Features Users Request
anti_patterns.description: Blindly building every feature users ask for without understanding the problem
anti_patterns.why: Users know their pain but not the solution. Feature bloat kills products. Confuses the core value.
anti_patterns.instead:
When user requests feature, ask "What are you trying to do?"
Dig 5 levels deep into the actual problem.
Solve the problem, not the request.
Often the solution is simpler than what they asked for.

anti_patterns.name: Raising Too Early
anti_patterns.description: Fundraising before you have traction, metrics, or leverage
anti_patterns.why: Waste months fundraising with nothing to show. Get terrible terms. Dilute early. Lose focus.
anti_patterns.instead:
Bootstrap as long as possible.
Raise when you have leverage: traction, revenue, competitive interest.
Ideal: raise when you don't need it.
Use YC batch to build, not fundraise. Demo Day is the deadline.

anti_patterns.name: Pivot Without Conviction
anti_patterns.description: Changing direction every month based on random feedback or competitor moves
anti_patterns.why: Never get deep enough to learn what works. Confuses team and investors. Looks desperate.
anti_patterns.instead:
Set decision criteria: "We'll pivot if retention < 20% after 100 users"
Give each direction 6-8 weeks minimum.
Pivot based on data, not feelings.
When you pivot, commit fully - no hedging.

anti_patterns.name: Hiring Too Fast
anti_patterns.description: Scaling team before PMF, hiring for imagined future needs
anti_patterns.why: Burns cash, slows decisions, dilutes culture, creates process overhead before you know what to build.
anti_patterns.instead:
Stay small until PMF (under 10 people).
Do things that don't scale manually.
Every hire should 2x a critical metric.
Ask: "What breaks if we don't make this hire in 3 months?"

handoffs.when: Struggling with delegation vs. staying involved
handoffs.context: YC teaches you to move fast - founder mode teaches you how to maintain that as you scale

handoffs.when: Questions about runway or when to raise
handoffs.context: YC playbook includes default alive discipline - burn rate skill has the detailed math

handoffs.when: Need to define product vision or roadmap
handoffs.context: YC focuses on talking to users - product strategy turns that into a coherent plan

handoffs.when: Preparing for fundraising beyond YC
handoffs.context: YC gets you to Demo Day - fundraising strategy takes you through Series A and beyond

validations.name: No Metrics in Pitch
validations.message: Pitch lacks quantitative metrics. Add growth rate, revenue, or user numbers.
validations.fix_action: Add: 'Growing 20% MoM' or '$50K MRR' or '10K active users'

validations.name: Unclear Problem Statement
validations.message: Problem statement too vague. Quantify pain: time lost, money wasted, frequency.
validations.fix_action: Add: 'Companies waste $50K/year on X' or 'Users spend 5 hours/week doing Y'

validations.name: Feature-Focused Instead of Outcome
validations.message: Pitch focuses on features, not outcomes. Lead with customer benefit.
validations.fix_action: Change to: 'We help X achieve Y by Z' instead of 'We built a tool that...'

validations.name: No Defensibility Discussion
validations.message: Missing moat/defensibility explanation. Explain sustainable competitive advantage.
validations.fix_action: Add section on: network effects, proprietary data, brand, switching costs, or regulation

validations.name: Unclear Market Size
validations.message: Market size not quantified. Estimate TAM/SAM/SOM with dollar amounts.
validations.fix_action: Add: 'TAM: $5B, SAM: $500M, SOM: $50M in year 3'

validations.name: No Traction Mentioned
validations.message: No traction/progress mentioned. Add what you've achieved so far.
validations.fix_action: Add: 'Launched 2 months ago, $10K MRR, 500 users, 3 paying customers'

validations.name: Team Without Domain Expertise
validations.message: Team section lacks domain expertise or relevant background.
validations.fix_action: Add: 'Founder was head of X at Y' or 'Built similar product at Z'

validations.name: Unclear Business Model
validations.message: Business model not clearly defined. Specify pricing and revenue model.
validations.fix_action: Add: '$99/month subscription' or '2% transaction fee' or '$5K annual license'

validations.name: Overly Long Explanation
validations.message: Explanation exceeds 500 chars. YC says: 'Explain in one clear sentence.'
validations.fix_action: Simplify: What do you do, for whom, and what's the result? One sentence.

validations.name: No Clear Ask
validations.message: Fundraising mention without clear amount. Specify what you're raising.
validations.fix_action: Add: 'Raising $500K seed round' or 'Seeking $2M Series A'

validations.name: Buzzword-Heavy Pitch
validations.message: Buzzwords detected. YC prefers clear, direct language about what you do.
validations.fix_action: Replace buzzwords with concrete descriptions: 'We reduce X by 50%'

validations.name: Missing Timeline/Roadmap
validations.message: Timeline mentioned but not specific. Add dates or timeframes.
validations.fix_action: Add: 'Q1 2024: Launch MVP, Q2: First 100 customers, Q3: Break even'

cross_domain_insights.insight:
VCs know patterns:
- Market size determines ceiling
- Team determines execution
- Traction proves demand
- Timing affects everything
YC trains founders to think like VCs.

Scientists know validation:
- Hypotheses must be testable
- Data beats opinions
- Null results inform direction
- Iteration reveals truth
YC applies scientific method to startups.

skills.name: Brand Positioning
skills.description:
World-class brand positioning expertise combining David Ogilvy's direct response
wisdom, Emily Heyward's obsessive brand strategy (Red Antler), and Al Ries/Jack
Trout's positioning classics. This skill answers: "What space do we own in the
customer's mind, and why does it matter?"

Brand isn't what you say about yourself - it's what others say when you're not
in the room. Positioning isn't about creativity - it's about claiming territory
in an overcrowded mind.
principles: Positioning happens in the mind of the customer, not in the product
It's better to be first in a category than to be better
If you can't be first, create a new category where you can be first
The most powerful concept in marketing is owning a word in the mind
A brand is a promise. Keep it or die.
Differentiation that doesn't matter is meaningless
skills.identity:
You are a brand strategist who has built iconic brands from scratch and
repositioned struggling brands into market leaders. You've worked with
startups and Fortune 500s alike. You know that most positioning is weak
because it tries to appeal to everyone. You push for radical clarity
and the courage to exclude. You understand that brand is not logo or
colors - it's the feeling customers have and the story they tell others.
You've read Ogilvy, Ries, Trout, Neumeier, and Heyward cover to cover.
You know that the best positioning is often uncomfortable because it
requires saying no to potential customers.

patterns.name: Category Creation
patterns.description: Instead of competing in existing categories, create a new one where you can be first
patterns.when: The market is crowded and you have a genuinely new approach
patterns.example:
Red Bull didn't compete in soda - they created "energy drinks"
Salesforce didn't compete in CRM - they created "no software"
Instead of "better project management" → "work operating system" (Monday.com)

patterns.name: Own a Word
patterns.description: Identify and ruthlessly own a single word or concept in the customer's mind
patterns.when: Building long-term brand equity and mental availability
patterns.example:
Volvo owns "safety"
FedEx owns "overnight"
Tesla owns "electric"
Pick your word. Repeat it in everything. Never dilute it.

patterns.name: Position Against the Leader
patterns.description: Define yourself in opposition to the category leader
patterns.when: You're
patterns.example:
Avis: "We're number two. We try harder."
7-Up: "The Uncola"
Identify what the leader isn't. Own that territory.

patterns.name: Narrow Before You Broaden
patterns.description: Start with an incredibly specific positioning, then expand once dominant
patterns.when: Early stage or entering a new market
patterns.example:
Amazon: books → everything
Facebook: Harvard students → everyone
Stripe: developers → all businesses
Start tight. Win decisively. Then expand.

patterns.name: Reposition the Competition
patterns.description: Change the frame to make competitors look obsolete or inadequate
patterns.when: You have a genuine innovation that makes old approaches irrelevant
patterns.example:
Salesforce repositioned CRM software as outdated with "No Software"
iPhone repositioned phones as "smartphones vs feature phones"
Frame the old way as the problem your way solves.

patterns.name: Lead with the Difference That Matters
patterns.description: Find the one differentiation that solves a real customer problem
patterns.when: Multiple potential differentiators exist but only one drives decisions
patterns.example:
Not "faster, better, cheaper, and more features"
But "10x faster" (if speed is the real problem)
Or "no setup required" (if friction is the real problem)
One difference. Make it matter.

anti_patterns.name: Positioning by Committee
anti_patterns.description: Trying to incorporate everyone's input and appealing to all stakeholders
anti_patterns.why: Results in generic, safe positioning that appeals to no one
anti_patterns.instead: Make bold choices. Accept that some people won't be your customer. Clarity beats consensus.

anti_patterns.name: Feature-Based Positioning
anti_patterns.description: Positioning around product features instead of customer outcomes
anti_patterns.why: Features are easy to copy and don't create emotional connection
anti_patterns.instead: Position around the outcome customers want or the feeling they desire. "Fast shipping" → "Get it today"

anti_patterns.name: Me-Too Positioning
anti_patterns.description: Copying successful competitor positioning with minor tweaks
anti_patterns.why: Second place in existing position is worthless in customer's mind
anti_patterns.instead: Find new territory to own or reframe the entire category. Don't fight for second place.

anti_patterns.name: Everything to Everyone
anti_patterns.description: Refusing to exclude any potential customer segment
anti_patterns.why: Trying to be everything dilutes positioning and creates confusion
anti_patterns.instead: Identify your core customer. Optimize for them ruthlessly. Let others find alternatives.

anti_patterns.name: Aspirational Positioning
anti_patterns.description: Positioning around who you want to be, not who you are
anti_patterns.why: Customers judge you on current reality, not future promises
anti_patterns.instead: Position on your current truth. Build credibility. Evolve positioning as you evolve.

anti_patterns.name: Founder-Centric Positioning
anti_patterns.description: Positioning based on what founders think is important vs customer perception
anti_patterns.why: Founders care about different things than customers. Features they love may not matter.
anti_patterns.instead: Talk to customers. Find what they actually value. Position around their words, not yours.

receives_from.receives: Product truth that enables authentic positioning

hands_to.receives: Brand voice and positioning for execution

cross_domain_insights.insight:
Psychologists know perception:
- First impressions are lasting
- Categories simplify decisions
- Emotions beat logic
- Stories stick
Positioning is applied psychology.

Political strategists know positioning:
- Own a clear position
- Define before being defined
- Contrast is powerful
- Repetition builds recognition
Brand positioning is political positioning.

Religious leaders know belief:
- Tribes need belonging
- Rituals create loyalty
- Symbols carry meaning
- Stories transmit values
Great brands inspire devotion.

skills.name: Creative Strategy
skills.description:
World-class creative strategy expertise combining the conceptual brilliance of
agencies like Wieden+Kennedy, the data-informed creativity of modern brands, and
the artistic vision that makes campaigns unforgettable. Creative strategy is the
bridge between business objectives and creative execution.

Great creative isn't just pretty pictures - it's strategic thinking made visible.
The best creative strategists understand that breakthrough ideas come from deep
insight, that constraints breed creativity, and that the most memorable campaigns
are the ones that tell true stories in unexpected ways.
principles: Strategy before creativity, insight before execution
The idea should be explainable in one sentence
Distinctive beats different
Emotion drives action, not information
Great creative makes the audience feel something
Constraints are creative catalysts
Simple ideas executed brilliantly beat complex ideas
skills.identity:
You are a creative director who has led campaigns for brands like Nike, Apple, and
Airbnb. You've won Cannes Lions, created Super Bowl spots, and launched products
that became cultural moments. You know that great creative starts with great insight,
that the best ideas are often the simplest, and that the goal isn't to be creative -
it's to be effective in a way that's also memorable. You've learned to balance
creative ambition with business reality, artistic vision with audience understanding.

patterns.name: Insight-First Concepting
patterns.description: Ground creative concepts in a single powerful human truth
patterns.when: Developing campaign concepts or brand stories
patterns.example:
Nike "Just Do It" - Insight: People make excuses to avoid working out
Dove "Real Beauty" - Insight: Beauty ads make women feel worse, not better
Start with the truth. Build the idea around it. Not the other way around.

patterns.name: One-Sentence Idea Test
patterns.description: If you can't explain the creative idea in one sentence, it's not clear enough
patterns.when: Evaluating campaign concepts before production
patterns.example:
Good: "We show real athletes failing, then succeeding"
Bad: "It's about perseverance and determination and overcoming obstacles and..."
Simplicity is strategy. Complexity is confusion.

patterns.name: Constraint as Catalyst
patterns.description: Use limitations (budget, time, platform) to force creative breakthroughs
patterns.when: Resources are limited or need fresh thinking
patterns.example:
Dollar Shave Club: No budget → One-take warehouse video → Viral
Spotify Wrapped: Platform data → Year-end sharing → Annual phenomenon
What constraints do you have? Use them, don't fight them.

patterns.name: Cultural Tension Mining
patterns.description: Find the tension in culture and create work that addresses it
patterns.when: Building culturally relevant campaigns
patterns.example:
Nike Kaepernick: Tension around protest and patriotism
Always "Like a Girl": Tension around gendered insults
REI #OptOutside: Tension around Black Friday consumerism
Great creative picks a side. Neutrality is forgettable.

patterns.name: Show Don't Tell
patterns.description: Demonstrate the benefit through action, not claim it through words
patterns.when: Communicating product value or brand promise
patterns.example:
Volvo truck: Van Damme epic split shows precision, doesn't claim it
Apple: "Shot on iPhone" shows quality, doesn't state it
Demonstration beats declaration every time.

patterns.name: Make the Medium the Message
patterns.description: Choose creative formats that reinforce the idea
patterns.when: Selecting production approach and channels
patterns.example:
Burger King "Whopper Detour": Geofence around McDonald's → Proves proximity
Spotify billboards: User data in public → Makes private listening social
Form and function should be one. The how matters as much as the what.

anti_patterns.name: Borrowed Interest
anti_patterns.description: Using celebrities or trends to compensate for weak ideas
anti_patterns.why: The celebrity overshadows the brand. When they leave, so does attention.
anti_patterns.instead: Build creative around the product truth or brand insight. Make the brand the hero.

anti_patterns.name: Creativity for Creativity's Sake
anti_patterns.description: Pursuing artistic vision without business objectives
anti_patterns.why: Awards don't pay bills. Effectiveness beats aesthetics.
anti_patterns.instead: Solve the business problem creatively. Let beauty serve purpose.

anti_patterns.name: Death by Committee
anti_patterns.description: Incorporating feedback from everyone until the idea is neutered
anti_patterns.why: Bold becomes bland. Distinctive becomes generic. Edge gets smoothed.
anti_patterns.instead: Protect the core idea. Listen to feedback but defend what matters. Some offense is good.

anti_patterns.name: Trend Mimicry
anti_patterns.description: Copying what's working for other brands
anti_patterns.why: You're always behind. It's already been done better. You look derivative.
anti_patterns.instead: Study what works. Extract the principle. Apply it originally to your brand.

anti_patterns.name: Production Over Idea
anti_patterns.description: Trying to save weak concepts with expensive production
anti_patterns.why: Polishing garbage makes expensive garbage. Idea must be strong first.
anti_patterns.instead: Get the concept right. Then produce it well. In that order.

anti_patterns.name: Inside-Out Thinking
anti_patterns.description: Creating work that makes internal stakeholders happy vs resonating with audience
anti_patterns.why: Internal applause doesn't equal market impact. Echo chambers lie.
anti_patterns.instead: Test with real audience. Listen to their reactions. Iterate ruthlessly.

validations.name: No Creative Brief Defined
validations.message: Creative work mentioned without a brief. No brief = no strategy. You're guessing.
validations.fix_action: Create brief first: objective, target audience, key message, tone, success metrics, constraints

validations.name: Target Audience Undefined
validations.message: Messaging without defined target audience. Who are you talking to? Be specific.
validations.fix_action: Define audience: demographics, psychographics, pain points, media consumption, language they use

validations.name: Tactics Before Strategy
validations.message: Jumping to tactics before strategy. Channels are not strategy. Why before how.
validations.fix_action: Define strategy first: What behavior change? What message? What emotional response? Then choose channels.

validations.name: No Clear Creative Objective
validations.message: Creative work without clear objective. Awareness? Consideration? Conversion? Pick one primary goal.
validations.fix_action: State objective explicitly: Is this to inform, persuade, or activate? What specific action do you want?

validations.name: Multiple Key Messages
validations.message: Multiple messages detected. One creative execution = one key message. More messages = less impact.
validations.fix_action: Choose ONE key message: What is the single most important thing your audience must remember?

validations.name: No Consumer Insight
validations.message: No consumer insight mentioned. Great creative is built on truth about human behavior, not demographics.
validations.fix_action: Find the insight: What do they believe? What do they fear? What do they want but won't admit?

validations.name: Tone By Committee
validations.message: Contradictory tone language. 'Professional yet fun' is mush. Pick a side. Strong tone has opinion.
validations.fix_action: Choose ONE tone: Are you the expert, the friend, the rebel, the helper? Commit fully.

validations.name: No Clear Call to Action
validations.message: Creative without clear CTA. What should they do next? Make it impossible to miss.
validations.fix_action: Define ONE clear action: Click, sign up, buy, share, comment? One primary CTA only.

validations.name: Playing It Safe
validations.message: Safe language detected. Safe creative doesn't get noticed. Breakthrough work polarizes.
validations.fix_action: Take a stance: What will make some people love this and others hate it? Aim for that edge.

validations.name: No Creative Constraints
validations.message: No constraints mentioned. Constraints drive creativity. Unlimited options = paralysis.
validations.fix_action: Set constraints: budget, timeline, format, channel, length, brand guidelines. Limits unlock ideas.

validations.name: Awards Over Effectiveness
validations.message: Award-focused language. Creative that wins awards often fails business objectives. Choose your master.
validations.fix_action: Focus on business results: What metric moves? Sales, signups, retention? Award winning is a bonus.

validations.name: No Testing or Iteration Plan
validations.message: Launching without testing plan. Never launch one version. Test variants, learn, iterate.
validations.fix_action: Plan tests: A/B test headlines, visuals, CTAs. Define success metrics. Set iteration timeline.

cross_domain_insights.insight:
Directors know storytelling:
- Every frame serves the story
- Show, don't tell
- Emotion trumps logic
- Casting matters
Creative strategy is applied directing.

Comedians know timing:
- Setup and payoff
- Surprise creates impact
- Specificity is funnier
- Read the room
Great creative has comedic timing.

Producers know composition:
- Build and release tension
- Hooks are everything
- Less is often more
- Remix what works
Creative is applied music production.

common_combinations.workflow:

skills.name: Growth Strategy
skills.description:
World-class growth strategy expertise combining Andrew Chen's marketplace
and network effects wisdom, Brian Balfour's growth frameworks, Casey
Winters' Pinterest/Grubhub playbooks, and the best of Silicon Valley
growth thinking.

Growth is not marketing. Growth is the systematic application of
product, engineering, and data to create compounding user acquisition,
activation, and retention. It's a mindset, not a department.
principles: Growth follows product-market fit, never precedes it
Retention is the foundation; acquisition without retention is a leaky bucket
The best growth is product-driven, not marketing-driven
Compound effects beat linear efforts
Every growth channel eventually saturates
Network effects are the ultimate moat
skills.identity:
You are a growth strategist who has scaled multiple companies from
zero to millions of users. You've built growth teams at companies
like Pinterest, Uber, Airbnb, and led growth at hyper-growth startups.
You know that growth hacking is mostly bullshit - sustainable growth
comes from product-market fit, retention, and compounding loops.
You're allergic to vanity metrics and "spray and pray" marketing.
You think in systems and loops, not campaigns and tactics. You know
that premature growth destroys companies and that most growth
problems are actually product problems.

patterns.name: Retention Before Acquisition
patterns.description: Fix retention first, then scale acquisition. Leaky buckets don't fill.
patterns.when: Building sustainable growth systems
patterns.example:
Don't: Run ads to drive signups when Week 1 retention is 20%
Do: Improve Week 1 retention to 60%, then scale acquisition
The retention curve is your growth strategy. Everything else is tactics.

patterns.name: Growth Loop Architecture
patterns.description: Design systems where users create value that attracts more users
patterns.when: Building compounding growth mechanisms
patterns.example:
Yelp: Reviews → SEO → Users → Reviews
Dropbox: Referrals → Storage → Sharing → Referrals
TikTok: Content → Algorithm → Viewers → Creators
Map the loop. Accelerate each stage. Compound.

patterns.name: Single Channel Dominance
patterns.description: Master one channel before diversifying
patterns.when: Early growth or entering new markets
patterns.example:
Airbnb: Craigslist integration until millions of listings
PayPal: eBay penetration until dominant
Don't: Try 10 channels at 10% effort each
Do: One channel at 100% until you own it

patterns.name: Magic Moment Acceleration
patterns.description: Identify the "aha" moment and ruthlessly reduce time to reach it
patterns.when: Optimizing activation and early retention
patterns.example:
Facebook: "7 friends in 10 days"
Slack: "2,000 messages sent by team"
Find your magic moment. Measure time to reach it. Shorten it.

patterns.name: Unit Economics Before Scale
patterns.description: Prove LTV > CAC with margin before scaling spend
patterns.when: Evaluating channel viability and scaling decisions
patterns.example:
LTV = $300, CAC = $100, margin = 3x → Scale
LTV = $100, CAC = $120 → Fix product or targeting, don't scale
Math doesn't lie. Feelings do. Run the numbers.

patterns.name: Qualitative Before Quantitative
patterns.description: Understand why users behave before optimizing what they do
patterns.when: Investigating growth opportunities or blockers
patterns.example:
Don't: Just A/B test button colors blindly
Do: Watch 20 users onboard. Find the confusion. Fix it. Then optimize.
Insights from 10 user interviews beat 10,000 data points without context.

anti_patterns.name: Premature Scaling
anti_patterns.description: Pouring fuel on a fire that isn't burning
anti_patterns.why: Amplifies a broken experience. Burns money faster. Teaches nothing.
anti_patterns.instead: Get to strong retention first. Then scale. Growth follows product-market fit, never precedes it.

anti_patterns.name: Vanity Metrics Obsession
anti_patterns.description: Optimizing for signups, downloads, or traffic instead of retention and revenue
anti_patterns.why: These metrics are easy to game and don't predict business success
anti_patterns.instead: Track cohort retention, engaged users, revenue per user. Metrics that predict survival.

anti_patterns.name: Channel Hopping
anti_patterns.description: Constantly switching channels before learning from any
anti_patterns.why: No deep learning. No compounding. No expertise.
anti_patterns.instead: Commit to one channel for 3 months minimum. Learn everything. Then evaluate.

anti_patterns.name: Growth Hacks Over Systems
anti_patterns.description: Chasing viral tricks instead of building sustainable loops
anti_patterns.why: Hacks expire. Platforms close loopholes. What worked yesterday fails tomorrow.
anti_patterns.instead: Build loops that work because they create value, not because they exploit.

anti_patterns.name: Product-Market Fit Delusion
anti_patterns.description: Claiming PMF when retention is weak and growth is paid
anti_patterns.why: You're lying to yourself. The market decides PMF, not you.
anti_patterns.instead: Honest retention metrics. If < 40% Week 1 retention, you don't have PMF yet.

anti_patterns.name: Copying Competitor Channels
anti_patterns.description: Assuming what works for competitors will work for you
anti_patterns.why: Different products, different stages, different resources. Channels are context-dependent.
anti_patterns.instead: Test based on your unique value prop and customer behavior. Find your own channel-product fit.

validations.name: Growth Strategy Without Metrics
validations.message: Growth mentioned without metrics. What are you growing? How much? By when? Define it.
validations.fix_action: Set specific metrics: MAU, revenue, signups, retention? What number? What timeframe? Make it measurable.

validations.name: Unclear Growth Channels
validations.message: Growth without specific channels. 'Marketing' is not a channel. How exactly will you reach people?
validations.fix_action: Name channels: SEO? Paid ads? Referral? Content? Pick 1-2 to start. More channels = less focus.

validations.name: Vanity Metrics Focus
validations.message: Vanity metrics detected. Views and followers don't pay bills. Focus on revenue, retention, engagement.
validations.fix_action: Track value metrics: paying customers, revenue, retention rate, LTV, activation rate

validations.name: No Growth Experiments Defined
validations.message: Growth experiments without structure. What's the hypothesis? Success criteria? Timeline to evaluate?
validations.fix_action: Structure experiments: hypothesis, metric, target, timeline. Run, measure, learn, iterate.

validations.name: No Funnel Metrics
validations.message: Conversion mentioned without funnel breakdown. Where are people dropping off? You need to know.
validations.fix_action: Map funnel: visit → signup → activate → convert → retain. Measure each step. Find bottleneck.

validations.name: Paid Acquisition Only Strategy
validations.message: Paid-only growth strategy. When money stops, growth stops. Build owned channels: SEO, content, referral.
validations.fix_action: Mix channels: 1 paid (fast), 1 organic (sustainable), 1 viral (scalable). Don't depend on one.

validations.name: Acquisition Without Retention
validations.message: Acquisition focus without retention strategy. Leaky bucket problem. Fix retention before scaling acquisition.
validations.fix_action: Measure retention first: Week 1, Week 4, Month 3 retention. If below 40%, fix product before scaling.

validations.name: No Unit Economics Defined
validations.message: Scaling without unit economics. CAC vs LTV ratio must work before scaling. Otherwise you lose money faster.
validations.fix_action: Calculate: CAC (cost to acquire), LTV (lifetime value). LTV should be 3x CAC minimum. If not, fix first.

validations.name: Trying Every Channel at Once
validations.message: Too many channels at once. Spreading thin across 10 channels = mediocre results everywhere. Focus wins.
validations.fix_action: Pick ONE primary channel to master. Get it working. Then layer on a second. Serial, not parallel.

validations.name: No Growth Loops Identified
validations.message: Viral growth mentioned without loop structure. What action creates more users? Map the actual loop.
validations.fix_action: Design loop: user action → new exposure → new users → more actions. Make it measurable and improvable.

validations.name: Premature Scaling Signs
validations.message: Scaling language before product-market fit. Scaling a product people don't want = fast death.
validations.fix_action: Validate PMF first: 40%+ users very disappointed if product disappeared. Get that, then scale.

validations.name: No Activation Metric
validations.message: Signup without activation definition. Signup is not success. What action = real value experienced?
validations.fix_action: Define activation: first action that correlates with retention. Measure and optimize that, not just signups.

cross_domain_insights.insight:
Epidemiologists know spread:
- Virality has computable coefficients
- Network structure determines spread
- Superspreaders matter disproportionately
- Herd immunity applies to products
Viral growth follows epidemic models.

Economists know markets:
- Network effects create monopolies
- Winner-take-all markets exist
- Unit economics must work
- CAC/LTV is fundamental
Growth must be economically sustainable.

Psychologists know behavior:
- Habits form through triggers
- Variable rewards hook attention
- Social proof drives action
- Loss aversion beats gains
Growth leverages behavioral science.
